definition: Dong Zhuo (-192), top general of late Han, usurped power in 189, murdered empress dowager and child emperor, killed in 192 by Lü Bu 呂布|吕布
surname Dong
to supervise/to direct/director
outstanding
surname Zhuo

sentences.english: And Dong Zhuo treated them with disrespect.
Zhang Fei stamped toward Dong Zhuo's tent, holding firmly a sharp sword.
sentences.chinese: 張飛蓋章的帳篷，董卓朝持有堅決一把利刃。

sentences.english: Dong Zhuo's fate will be unrolled in later chapters.
sentences.chinese: 董卓的命運將會在後面的章節中展開。

sentences.english: Cao Cao, a wise and resourceful army officer, had long wanted to kill Dong Zhuo.
sentences.chinese: 校尉曹操，足智多謀並早有殺董卓之心。

sentences.english: Completed the Elimination of Dong Zhuo with one of the forces in Story Mode.
sentences.chinese: 在故事模式中和另一個勢力完成“消滅董卓”。

definition: Yuan Shao (153-202), general during late Han, subsequently warlord
Liu Biao (142-208), warlord
Lü Bu (-198), general and warlord

Cao Cao (155-220), famous statesman and general at the end of Han, noted poet and calligrapher, later warlord, founder and first king of Cao Wei 曹魏, father of Emperor Cao Pi 曹丕/the main villain of novel the Romance of Three Kingdoms 三國演義|三国演义
Huangfu Song (-195), later Han general and warlord
Ma Chao (176-222), general of Shu in Romance of the Three Kingdoms
Emperor Xian of Han (181-234), the final Han emperor, set up by Dong Zhuo 董卓, reigned 189-220, forced to abdicate 220 by Cao Pi 曹丕
Ten Permanent Functionaries at the end of Han, a byword for corruption
Liu Bei (161-223), warlord at the end of the Han dynasty and founder of the Han kingdom of Shu 蜀漢|蜀汉 (c. 200-263), later the Shu Han dynasty
Zhu Jun (-195), politician and general at the end of later Han
Sun Ce (175-200), general and major warlord of the Later Han Dynasty
Sun Quan (reigned 222-252), southern warlord and king of state of Wu 吳|吴 in the Three Kingdoms period
Cao Wei, the most powerful of the Three Kingdoms, established as a dynasty in 220 by Cao Pi 曹丕, son of Cao Cao, replaced by Jin dynasty in 265
Cao Pi (187-226), second son of Cao Cao 曹操, king then emperor of Cao Wei 曹魏 from 220, ruled as Emperor Wen 魏文帝, also a noted calligrapher
Xun Yu (163-212), brilliant strategist, advisor of Cao Cao in Three Kingdoms
the army of Yellow Turbans, a peasant uprising at the end of later Han (from 184)
